Legal_Issue: Improper assessment of evidence, inadequate evaluation of factors, bias concerns in H&C decision
Application_Facts: Applicants' financial status, integration into Canadian society, best interests of the child, prior decisions, and new evidence were considered
Decision_Outcome: No undue hardship found; application refused
Court_Ruling: Application dismissed; no reviewable error found
Defendant_Behavior: H&C officer conducted fair review without bias
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged procedural unfairness, inadequate hardship assessment, potential bias
Legal_Standard: Reasonableness for H&C decisions; correctness for procedural fairness
Assessment_Factor: Financial status, integration, best interests of the child, hardship
Procedural_Issue: Alleged inadequate reasoning and procedural unfairness
Review_Standard: Reasonableness for H&C assessment; correctness for procedural fairness
Evidence_Used: Financial documents, integration evidence, child welfare considerations, prior application records
Application_Basis: Humanitarian and Compassionate (H&C) grounds for permanent residence
Evidence_Assessed: Prior decisions, new evidence submitted by applicants
Relief_Sought: Certification of question of general importance, judicial review
Governing_Rule: H&C decisions must be reasonable, consider hardship and procedural fairness; bias must be substantiated
Cause_Description: Refusal of humanitarian and compassionate grounds for permanent residence
Evidence_Handling: Officer reviewed prior decisions and new evidence fairly
Evidence_Assessment: Comprehensive and fair evaluation of all relevant evidence
Decision_Rationale: No reviewable error; decision was reasonable and procedurally fair
